title: Fractional Distance
content: {x} denotes the distance from x to the nearest integer. Also define countTo(A, x) as the number of elements of A up to x.

title: Growth Condition
content: The growth condition requires |A ∩ [1,2x]| - |A ∩ [1,x]| → ∞. This means A has infinitely many elements in each sufficiently long dyadic interval.

title: Irrationality Condition
content: The irrationality condition requires Σ{θn} = ∞ for all θ ∈ (0,1). Intuitively, the fractional parts θn are well-distributed, far from integers.

title: Erdős's Conjecture
content: If A satisfies both conditions, then every sufficiently large integer is representable as a sum of distinct elements of A.

title: Cassels's Theorem (1960)
content: Cassels proved the conjecture under stronger conditions: (1) growth divided by log log x → ∞, (2) sum of {θn}² = ∞. This establishes the result with faster growth but weaker irrationality.

title: The Gap Between Conditions
content: Erdős's growth condition is weaker (just → ∞), Cassels's is stronger (/ log log x → ∞). For irrationality, Erdős uses Σ{θn}, Cassels uses Σ{θn}². The gap remains open.

title: Powers of 2 Example
content: The set {1, 2, 4, 8, ...} satisfies both conditions. Every positive integer is a sum of distinct powers of 2 (binary representation).

title: Related Problems
content: Connection to the NP-complete subset sum problem (here conditions guarantee existence for large n) and to Sidon sets (unique vs existence of representations).

title: Problem Status and Summary
content: Erdős Problem #254 is OPEN. Cassels (1960) proved a related result but under strictly stronger hypotheses. Closing the gap between Erdős's and Cassels's conditions remains an open challenge.
